awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Robots in the Real World
awd_abstract_narration:
Robotics is an extremely multi-disciplinary field that incorporates ideas from mechanical engineering, electrical engineering, computer science, and beyond. Roboticists must consider aspects of systems from mechanical design to planning to understanding the needs of people who interact with robots; as such, the broad range of skills needed to be a roboticist makes it both a challenging and enriching field for many undergraduates. Despite this appeal, certain obstacles often interfere with undergraduate participation in robotics research, including lack of robotics infrastructure at home institutions and pipeline challenges for groups of students who are underrepresented in engineering. This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site renewal project particularly aims to address the above diversity and inclusion topics and improve program evaluation while preserving past successful aspects of the Site.

Undergraduate students at this REU Site will work on active research projects, contributing to new findings in a wide range of robotics research areas, from modeling robots to understanding human psychology as it applies to interactions with robots. The summer project work will fall under the domains of Oregon State University robotics faculty and affiliates, and all projects will focus on robotics research contributions that involve physical robots deployed in real-world settings. These projects involve autonomous robots to explore extreme ocean environments, telepresence robots, and next generation social robots. The REU student experience will involve formulating and pursuing robotics research questions under the supervision of leading faculty in one of the highest-ranked graduate robotics programs in the country. Historically, approximately 20 program participants have co-authored peer-reviewed academic papers that advanced the state of knowledge in the field based on their summer research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
Between this REU Site award and two past funded Robots in the Real World REU Site awards, we have run 11 iterations of the Oregon State University summer REU program in robotics. In total, over 175 students (selected from more than 1600 applicants) have participated in our cumulative REU Site programming to date, including students funded from our past REU Sites, students funded by other REU supplements, and additional summer undergraduate researchers in robotics. This inclusion of more summer researchers than just those funded by the core site extends the reach of our REU programming efforts. The overall cohort of students was exposed to all aspects of graduate student life, interacted daily with peer/graduate/faculty mentors, and benefitted from seminar programming intended to build graduate research readiness.

During the term of this award, 56 REU students participated in our site, including 32 students funded directly by the REU Site and 24 supported by supplements and/or adjacent REU Site awards. 72 students overall participated in the REU Site seminars and other programming; this count includes undergraduate robotics researchers from other programs on campus, as well as high school robotics research trainees. Among the 56 REU students specifically, 29 were female, 28 had limited research opportunities at their home universities, 18 identified as an underrepresented race in STEM (as defined by the NSF), at least eight were first-generation college students, and 10 identified as having a disability.

Student research effort topics ranged from robotic fruit harvesting and soft robotics to underwater manipulation and human-robot interaction. As part of the REU program, students presented their research three times over the course of the summer. Many students also went on to coauthor peer-reviewed academic publications about their summer research experience work. To date, at least 22 of the REU participants co-authored published research papers, with more works in preparation. In robotics, authoring work like this is one of the most important pre-steps for being admitted into competitive graduate robotics programs. Accordingly, the academic writing and publishing experience undertaken as part of the REU work can provide past participants with a significant boost in future career steps within our graduate program and other top programs. Currently, three past REU students are completing their PhDs in our robotics program.


Last Modified: 02/05/2025
Modified by: Naomi T Fitter
